Archive for 2019:

Six Hours to Midnight: GSOMIA and the US Indo-Pacific Strategy Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/11/25/six-hours-to-midnight-gsomia-and-the-us-indo-pacific-strategy/

By Anthony Rinna Link: https://sinonk.com/author/anthony-rinna/ | November 25, 2019

South Korea’s narrowly-avoided decision to terminate GSOMIA underscores how the ROK’s defense priorities in Northeast Asia affect the US’s Indo-Pacific strategy as a whole.

Live from Korea, live from anywhere: a review of “K-pop Live: Fans, Idols, and Multimedia Performance” Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/11/18/live-from-korea-live-from-anywhere-a-review-of-k-pop-live-fans-idols-and-multimedia-performance/

By Wonseok Lee Link: https://sinonk.com/author/wonseok-lee/ | November 18, 2019

Musician and scholar Wonseok Lee, in his debut publication for Sino-NK, offers a review of Suk-young Kim’s “K-Pop Live: Fans, Idols and Media Performance”.

Understanding North Korea: Foreign Relations of North Korea in 2000 Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/11/04/understanding-north-korea-foreign-relations-of-north-korea-in-2000/

By Yujin Lim Link: https://sinonk.com/author/yujinlimm/ | November 04, 2019

In this translation from the original Korean, analyst Yujin Lim offers a glimpse of how Seoul perceived Pyongyang’s program of diplomatic outreach in the year 2000, offering observers a chance to peer into the origins of contemporary North Korean foreign policy.

Yongusil 98: Moscow and the Dilemma of Regional Development versus North Korea Sanctions Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/09/30/yongusil-98-moscow-and-the-dilemma-of-regional-development-versus-north-korea-sanctions/

By Anthony Rinna Link: https://sinonk.com/author/anthony-rinna/ | September 30, 2019

Russia’s North Korea policy involves a trade-off: refusal to support UN sanctions hurts Russia internationally, but supporting sanctions damages growth prospects in the country’s easternmost regions. Anthony Rinna covers this dilemma in Asian Studies International Review.

Yongusil 97: On the Academic Misconduct of Charles Armstrong, and Sino-NK’s 2013 Roundtable Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/09/25/yongusil-97-on-the-academic-misconduct-of-charles-armstrong-and-sino-nks-2013-roundtable/

By Sino-NK Link: https://sinonk.com/author/sinonkblog/ | September 25, 2019

With the field of Korean Studies (hopefully) chastened by the exposure of Charles Armstrong’s misconduct, Sino-NK reflects on the case and our role in it.

Yongusil 96: Russia, South Korea and the New Northern Policy Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/07/01/yongusil-96-russia-south-korea-and-the-new-northern-policy/

By Anthony Rinna | July 01, 2019

It is common for Seoul to have a special program dedicated to solidifying economic ties with Russia. But as Anthony Rinna writes in a new paper for the Journal of Eurasian Studies, several factors are set to hinder success once again.

55 Remnants of Conflict: The Korean War Prisoners Who Chose Brazil Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/05/23/55-remnants-of-conflict-the-korean-war-prisoners-who-chose-brazil/

By Leonardo Barbosa Link: https://sinonk.com/author/leonardo-barbosa/ | May 23, 2019

At the end of the Korean War, 88 North Korean and Chinese POWs decided to gamble on lives in third countries, eschewing South Korea and Taiwan. 55 were resettled in Brazil. These are their stories.

Law, Order, and Heroin in Dandong Link: https://sinonk.com/2019/05/20/law-order-and-heroin-in-dandong/

By Adam Cathcart Link: https://sinonk.com/author/adamcathcart/ | May 20, 2019

The border city of Dandong maintains an important position for the Chinese Communist Party in its relations with the Kim Jong-un regime. Adam Cathcart investigates the latest sources.

What is Sino-NK?

Sino-NK is a scholarly collective of young Sinologists and Koreanists dedicated to documenting and analyzing the borderland dynamics, transnational ties, and history of Northeast Asia. Work published on Sino-NK is regularly cited in journalistic outlets and our analysts have been featured in a range of academic publications. Sino-NK endeavors to better understand North Korea’s relations with the world and to chart a path forward for digital (and) academic analysis. Read more Link: https://sinonk.com/about-us/
